--- In junit@y..., "Eric George" <zymurgist2@h...> wrote:
> The solution here is to make sure the shared classes are in the 
*classpath*
> of the JUnit.
> 
> The problem is actually caused by the hierarchical class loading 
mechanism
> in JDK 1.3+.  Since JUnit uses a custom class loader, and RMI uses 
a custom
> class loader, any class that is loaded by JUnit *and* loaded 
automatically
> during a remote call will come from two different class loaders and 
will
> fail a class comparison.  It is a bizarre thing, but I have come 
accross it
> may times when RMI client classes are loaded by any custom 
classloader.  It
> happens often with RMI clients that are servlets since servlets are 
usually
> loaded by the servlet containers' custom class loader.
> 
> The real solution would be to set the RMIClassLoader's parent 
classloader to
> that of the JUnit custom class loader.  This is not possible 
however, so the
> RMIClassLoader's parent is *always* the system classloader.  There 
are
> several bugs logged against the RMI subsystem because of this.
> 
> In the meantime, the only workaround is to ensure all classes that 
are
> shared between the server and the custom-class-loaded client are 
available
> in the client's classpath.
>
